#Text=Governor Blacksnake
#Text=Tah-won-ne-ahs or Thaonawyuthe ( born between 1737 and 1760 , died 1859 ) , known in English as either Governor Blacksnake or Chainbreaker , was a Seneca war chief and leader .
#Text=Along with other Iroquois war chiefs ( most notably Mohawk leader Joseph Brant ) , he led warriors to fight on the side of the British during the American Revolutionary War from 1777 to 1783 .
#Text=He was prominent for his role at the Battle of Oriskany , in which the Loyalist and allied forces ambushed a force of rebels ( now called Patriots ) . [ 1 ]
#Text=After the war he supported his maternal uncle Handsome Lake , as a prominent religious leader .

#Text=Governor Blacksnake allied with the United States in the War of 1812 and later encouraged some accommodation to European-American settlers , allowing missionaries and teachers on the Seneca reservation .
#Text=Importantly , he also led a successful postwar struggle in New York in the 1850s after white men illegally bought reservation land .
#Text=He helped gain a New York State Appeals Court ruling in 1861 that restored the Oil Springs Reservation to the Seneca . [ 2 ]
#Text=Early life
#Text=Governor Blacksnake was born near Seneca Lake in western New York in the Seneca/Cayuga village of Kendaia ( Apple Town ) . [ 3 ]
#Text=His mother was a Seneca woman of the Wolf clan and his father was known as De-ne-oh-ah-te or "

#Text=After the Revolutionary War , in 1788 Chainbreaker moved to the large area of land in Pennsylvania granted to his uncle Cornplanter for his service by the state legislature , after his home village ( Canawaugus ) was sold to the United States in the Phelps and Gorham Purchase of Seneca lands .
#Text=Converted to his uncle Handsome Lake 's religion , Chainbreaker became an active promoter of traditional ways .
#Text=In 1803 he moved with Handsome Lake to nearby Coldspring , after a dispute with Cornplanter . [ 6 ]

#Text=While Blacksnake continued to advocate " temperance , morality , and adherence to the overall principles of Handsome Lake , " he rejected his uncle 's " proscription against Indian participation in the ' white man 's wars " . [ 6 ]

column1: #Text=By the 1840s Blacksnake had formulated his own version of his uncle 's traditional ways .
#Text=He generally urged finding a path of compromise .
#Text=He permitted missionaries and Western schooling on the Reservation and encouraged his followers to work toward social harmony and to take advantage of schooling . [ 6 ]
#Text=Involvement in regional warfare
#Text=In 1777

#Text=Blacksnake took part in the siege of Fort Stanwix and the Battle of Oriskany in British General St. Leger 's part of the Saratoga campaign . In 1778 he participated in the Battle of Wyoming under the command of Colonel John Butler .
#Text=In 1779 he attempted to defend Seneca settlements against the raid of Colonel Daniel Brodhead . [ 7 ]
#Text=Blacksnake carried messages for the British on a trail that passed through today 's Napoli , New York . [ 8 ]

#Text=After his work on behalf of the British in the Revolutionary War , Chainbreaker became reconciled to the United States establishing independence and forcing the Seneca and other Iroquois from most of their lands .
#Text=He volunteered to fight on the American side in the War of 1812 , [ 2 ] and participated in the Battle of Fort George . [ 1 ]
#Text=Struggle for Oil Spring Reservation
#Text=Photograph of Governor Blacksnake , ( Tha-o-na-wyuthe ) or ( " Tha -- o-wa-nyuths , " ) " The Nephew " ( Seneca ) .
#Text=Governor Blacksnake " helped save the Oil Spring Reserve " for the Seneca .
#Text=His victory in this New York State court case established a precedent for the land claim settled in June 2005 over Cuba Lake . [ 9 ]
#Text=After the war , European Americans Stanley Clark , Benjamin Chamberlain , and William Gallagher bought lands adjacent to the Seneca Oil Spring Reservation .
#Text=On behalf of these three men , Clark surveyed Reservation lands and claimed the area , granting one-quarter of the reservation to Horatio Seymour , later elected as governor of New York .
#Text=In the 1850s , Clark conveyed another quarter to Philonius Pattison .
#Text=In response to these actions , the Seneca filed a legal challenge that reached the New York Court of Appeals , Seneca Nation of Indians v. Philonus Pattison .
#Text=They protested against the Seymour , Gallagher , Chamberlain , and Clark claims to the northeast quarter of Oil Spring .

#Text=Governor Blacksnake , who had attended the negotiations of the Treaty of Big Tree that established the reservation , testified that he and Joseph Ellicott had surveyed the Oil Spring lands and that the omission of a full legal description of the lands from the treaty was a mistake .
#Text=He produced a map copied by the Holland Land Company , in which the Oil Spring Reservation was marked similarly to other Seneca lands .
#Text=In 1861 , the Court found for the Seneca Nation .
#Text=Pattison , Chamberlain , Clark , Gallagher , and Seymour were forced to leave the reservation .

#Text=While later incursions by the New York State Board of Canal Commissioners and tourist activities have taken additional land from the Reservation , Governor Blacksnake 's actions helped preserve some of Oil Spring as Seneca land . [ 10 ]
#Text=Later life
#Text=In later life , Chainbreaker 's political influence waned , as younger Seneca men assumed control . [ 11 ]
#Text=But he continued to participate in the Iroquois Condolence Council into his nineties . [ 12 ]
#Text=Blacksnake died on the Allegany Reservation in Cattaraugus County , New York in late December 1859 .
#Text=He is remembered by the Seneca Nation as " a man of rare intellectual and moral power .
